model¶

The base model for predictions is the EncodeProcessDecode graph convolutional network as defined by Battaglia (2018).

Uncertainty Quantification¶

The estimation of the epistemic uncertainty (EU), i.e. the level of confidence of the model in its own prediction, has been implemented in three different ways:

  • Ensemble : trains \(n\) models. The EU is taken to be the variance between the predictions of the single models.

  • MCDropout : train one model with dropout layers. At inference time, perform \(T\) forward passes with the dropout layers active and use the variance of the predictions as the EU.

  • ZigZag : train one model to recognize correct input-output pairs by feeding it back its own predictions. Use the squared difference of the two predictions as the EU. Comes in two flavors: the classic, where the feedback is done with the output, and the “latent” where the feedback is done with the hidden features of the last layer.

Classes

DropoutMLP(inputs, targets, hidden, p)

Simple multilayer perceptron with dropout layers.

EncodeProcessDecode(node_features, ...[, ...])

Complete convolutional graph neural network "à la Google".

Ensemble class.

GNNBlock(node_features, edge_features[, ...])

A graph-convolutional block "à la Google".

MCDropout(node_features, edge_features, ...)

Class for graph-net MC Dropout method for epistemic uncertainty evaluation.

MiniMLP(inputs, targets, hidden)

Simple multilayer perceptron.

ZigZag(node_features, edge_features, ...[, ...])

Implementation of ZigZag to estimate the epistemic uncertainty of a graph network.
class model.DropoutMLP(inputs: int, targets: int, hidden: List[int], p: float)¶

Bases: MiniMLP

Simple multilayer perceptron with dropout layers.

Parameters:

  • inputs (int) – dimensionality of the input

  • targets (int) – dimensionality of the output

  • hidden (List[int]) – dimensionaly of the hidden layers

  • p (float) – probability of dropout

forward(x: Tensor) → Tensor¶

Forward pass through the network.

Parameters:

x (torch.Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (batch_size, inputs)

Returns:

Output tensor of shape (batch_size, targets)

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class model.EncodeProcessDecode(node_features: int, edge_features: int, hidden_features: int, n_blocks: int, out_nodes: int, out_glob: int, dropout: bool | None = False, p: float | None = 0.1)¶

Bases: Module

Complete convolutional graph neural network “à la Google”. The data flow is composed of three stages: 1. Encode the features using an MLP 2. Process the latent features using various GNNBlock in series 3. Global aggregate and process global features 4. Decode node features using an MLP

Parameters:

  • node_features (int) – dimensionality of the input node features

  • edge_features (int) – dimensionality of the input edge features

  • hidden_features (int) – dimensionality of the hidden features

  • n_blocks (int) – number of GNNBlock in the processor

  • out_nodes (int) – dimensionality of the output node features

  • out_glob (int) – dimensionality of the output global features

  • dropout (bool, optional) – whether to include dropout layers in the mini-MLPs (default False)

  • p (float, optional) – probability of dropout (default 0.1)

forward(data: Data, return_hidden: bool = False) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]¶

Forward pass through the network.

Parameters:

  • data (Data) – Input graph

  • return_hidden (bool, optional) – if True, returns also the activations of the last layer (default False)

Returns:

Output tensors for node features, global features and activations of the last layer (if return_hidden=True)

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]

class model.Ensemble(n_models: int, node_features: int, edge_features: int, hidden_features: int, n_blocks: int, out_nodes: int, out_glob: int)¶

Bases: Module

Ensemble class. See it as a list of models, to be trained independently. The base model is the EncodeProcessDecode GNN, see its documentation for a complete list of inputs.

Parameters:

n_models (int) – number of particles in the ensemble.

forward(data: Data, return_var: bool = False) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]¶

Performs a forward pass in the network.

Parameters:

  • data (Data) – input graph

  • return_var (bool, optional) – if True, return prediction and variance by computing the variance of the predictions of the single models.

class model.GNNBlock(node_features: int, edge_features: int, aggr: str | List[str] | Aggregation | None = 'sum', dropout: bool | None = False, p: float | None = 0.1, *, aggr_kwargs: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, flow: str = 'source_to_target', node_dim: int = -2, decomposed_layers: int = 1)¶

Bases: MessagePassing

A graph-convolutional block “à la Google”. Start by updating edges using a MLP (with a single hidden layer), then propagate the values to the neighborhood of every node using the aggregation function. Finally, update the node features using another MLP. For the complete documentation of the inputs, see MessagePassing class.

Parameters:

  • node_features (int) – dimensionality of the node features

  • edge_features (int) – dimensionality of the edge features

  • aggr (str, List[str] or Aggregation, optional) – aggregation function. See documentation of MessagePassing class (default "sum")

  • dropout (bool, optional) – whether to include dropout layers in the mini-MLPs (default False)

  • p (float, optional) – probability of dropout (default 0.1)

aggregate(inputs, index, dim_size=None)¶

Aggregates messages from neighbors as \(\bigoplus_{j \in \mathcal{N}(i)}\).

Takes in the output of message computation as first argument and any argument which was initially passed to propagate().

By default, this function will delegate its call to the underlying Aggregation module to reduce messages as specified in __init__() by the aggr argument.

forward(x, edge_index, edge_attr) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]¶

Runs the forward pass of the module.

message(x_i, x_j, edge_attr)¶

Constructs messages from node \(j\) to node \(i\) in analogy to \(\phi_{\mathbf{\Theta}}\) for each edge in edge_index. This function can take any argument as input which was initially passed to propagate(). Furthermore, tensors passed to propagate() can be mapped to the respective nodes \(i\) and \(j\) by appending _i or _j to the variable name, .e.g. x_i and x_j.

class model.MCDropout(node_features: int, edge_features: int, hidden_features: int, n_blocks: int, out_nodes: int, out_glob: int, dropout: bool | None = True, p: float | None = 0.1)¶

Bases: EncodeProcessDecode

Class for graph-net MC Dropout method for epistemic uncertainty evaluation. Based on the EncodeProcessDecode class, see its documentation for complete list of inputs.

forward(data: Data, T: int | None = 1, return_var: bool = False)¶

Performs a forward pass in the network.

Parameters:

  • data (Data) – input graph

  • T (int, optional) – how many forward passes are used in the network (default 1)

  • return_var (bool, optional) – if True, return prediction and variance by calling the model twice.

class model.MiniMLP(inputs: int, targets: int, hidden: List[int])¶

Bases: Module

Simple multilayer perceptron.

Parameters:

  • inputs (int) – dimensionality of the input

  • targets (int) – dimensionality of the output

  • hidden (List[int]) – dimensionaly of the hidden layers

Forward pass through the network.

Parameters:

x (torch.Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (batch_size, inputs)

Returns:

Output tensor of shape (batch_size, targets)

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class model.ZigZag(node_features: int, edge_features: int, hidden_features: int, n_blocks: int, out_nodes: int, out_glob: int, z0: float | None = 0.0, latent: bool | None = False)¶

Bases: EncodeProcessDecode

Implementation of ZigZag to estimate the epistemic uncertainty of a graph network. ZigZag is based in the intuition that a neural network can be trained to recognize its own outputs, so that if it commits a mistake it should be able to detect it. To see a complete list of inputs, see EncodeProcessDecode.

Parameters:

  • z0 (float, optional) – constant for first pass in the network (default 0.0)

  • latent (bool, optional) – if True, loop the last latent feature instead of the output (default False)

forward(data: Data, y: Tensor | None = None, return_var: bool = False, return_hidden: bool = False) → Tuple[Tensor, Tensor]¶

Performs a forward pass in the network.

Parameters:

  • data (Data) – input graph

  • y (Tensor, optional) – feedback loop. If None, uses self.z0 (default None)

  • return_var (bool, optional) – if True, return prediction and variance by calling the model twice.

  • return_hidden (bool, optional) – if True, returns also the activations of the last layer (default False)
